channel.title: Comments on: The Lazy DBA Series: SQL Trace / Profiler

item.content:encoded:
“of course, 2 minutes based on table size”

On-P-N-T, Did you just give me a silent “D’oh!”?? ðŸ˜› Thanks for the reply ðŸ™‚ Looking forward to the next posts.

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: just be careful with SELECT INTO and tempdb with large tables because it could create locking
item.content:encoded: just be careful with SELECT INTO and tempdb with large tables because it could create locking

item.title: By: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.dc:creator: Ted Krueger (onpnt)
item.content:encoded:
Hi Janice,

ðŸ™‚ of course, 2 minutes based on table size ðŸ˜›

SELECT INTO typically outperforms a lot in that instance. Large tables, batch them up with SSIS as backups into DBs that are running in SIMPLE recovery in order to minimize huge log growth from it.

item.title: By: Janice Lee
item.dc:creator: Janice Lee
item.description: To clarify...I'm familiar w/ the different methods; just wanted to know which method you normally use. SSIS? BCP? I've always wanted to know what's the fastest (and "laziest"). ;)<br />
item.content:encoded: To clarify…I’m familiar w/ the different methods; just wanted to know which method you normally use. SSIS? BCP? I’ve always wanted to know what’s the fastest (and “laziest”). ðŸ˜‰

item.title: By: Janice Lee
item.dc:creator: Janice Lee
item.content:encoded:
Lazy Ted,

“4.Backup the table(s) (2 minutes)”

I must have just missed it but anyway, how would this 2-minute step be done?

Thanks!
